response.answer_text: Madame Curie’s name was Marie Curie. I don’t know why people her Madame Curie. I grew up thinking of her as just Madame Curie, as though Madame was her first name. I wonder if that women’s first names were not used very often and career women, especially women in science, were so rare that they called her Madame? To me it’s like calling Stephen Hawking, Mr. Hawking, which is fine and all but it seems rather personal. You’d think when I was reading about Marie Curie in my science textbook in Elementary school it would have said Marie instead of Madame, but it didn’t. She won two Nobel prizes and is the only person to win two prizes in two different sciences. She coined the term radioactivity and discovered polonium and radium. She was an innovative scientist, inventor, and a feminist.

She was a brilliant scientist who lived in the late 1800s and early 1900s. She discovered several radioactive elements, including Radium and is the only person to will 2 Nobel prizes both in science (she won for Physics and for Chemistry).
